content:
The Hidden Rate Elimination Act of 2001, also known as the Reduction in Marginal Income Tax Rates for Individuals, amends the 1986 Code to reduce tax rates for married individuals filing jointly and surviving spouses. This Act does not affect the tax rate change under section 15 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax rates based on taxable income are as follows:
- Not over $12,000: 14% of taxable income
- Over $12,000 but not over $45,200: $1,680 plus 15% of the excess over $12,000
- Over $45,200 but not over $109,250: $6,660 plus 27% of the excess over $45,200
- Over $109,250 but not over $166,450: $23,953.50 plus 30% of the excess over $109,250
- Over $166,450 but not over $297,300: $41,113.50 plus 35% of the excess over $166,450
- Over $297,300: $86,911 plus 38% of the excess over $297,300. Heads of Households are subject to a separate tax on their taxable income. The tax imposed on heads of households is $86,911 plus 38% of the excess over $297,300. Tax rates for taxable income vary based on different income brackets. For example, for taxable income not over $10,000, the tax rate is 14%. For income over $10,000 but not over $36,250, the tax is $1,400 plus 15% of the excess over $10,000. The tax rates increase progressively for higher income brackets. Tax rates for unmarried individuals are determined based on taxable income brackets. For income over $297,300, a tax of $89,217 plus 38% of the excess is imposed. This applies to individuals who are not married, surviving spouses, or heads of households. Tax rates for married individuals filing separate returns are based on taxable income brackets. For income not over $6,000, the tax is 14% of taxable income. For income over $6,000 but not over $27,050, the tax is $840 plus 15% of the excess over $6,000. For income over $27,050 but not over $65,550, the tax is $3,997.50 plus 27% of the excess over $27,050. For income over $65,550 but not over $136,750, the tax is $14,362.50 plus 30% of the excess over $65,550. For income over $136,750 but not over $297,300, the tax is $35,752.50 plus 35% of the excess over $136,750. For income over $297,300, the tax is $91,945 plus 38% of the excess over $297,300. For married individuals filing separate returns, a tax of $91,945 plus 38% of the excess over $297,300 is imposed on taxable income. The tax rates for different income brackets are as follows:
- Not over $6,000: 14% of taxable income
- Over $6,000 but not over $22,600: $840, plus 15% of the excess over $6,000
- Over $22,600 but not over $54,625: $3,330, plus 27% of the excess over $22,600
- Over $54,625 but not over $83,225: $11,976.75, plus 30% of the excess over $54,625
- Over $83,225 but not over $148,650: $20,556.75, plus 35% of the excess over $83,225
- Over $148,650: $43,455.50, plus 38% of the excess over $148,650. The tax rates for different income brackets are being phased in gradually, with reductions in rates for taxable years beginning after 2002. This includes reductions of 1 percentage point each year for certain brackets, such as the 14 percent rate, and additional reductions for others in specific years. The tax rates for various income brackets are gradually decreasing, with reductions of 1 percentage point each year for specific brackets starting after 2002. Additional reductions are also implemented in certain years, such as an extra 1 percentage point in 2004 and 2 percentage points in 2006 for the 30 and 38 percent rates. The Secretary will adjust the tables to reflect these reductions. Inflation adjustments will apply to determine rates for 2002. The tax rates for different income brackets will decrease gradually, with reductions of 1 percentage point annually for specific brackets starting after 2002. Additional reductions will be implemented in certain years, such as an extra 1 percentage point in 2004 and 2 percentage points in 2006 for the 30 and 38 percent rates. The Secretary will adjust the tables accordingly, and inflation adjustments will determine rates for 2002 and beyond. The tax rates for different income brackets will gradually decrease, with reductions of 1 percentage point annually for specific brackets starting after 2002. Additional reductions will be implemented in certain years, such as an extra 1 percentage point in 2004 and 2 percentage points in 2006 for the 30 and 38 percent rates. The cost-of-living adjustment used for dollar amounts will be determined by substituting '2005' for '2000' in various sections. Repeal of phaseouts of deduction for personal exemptions and itemized deductions. Repeal of Phaseout of Personal Exemptions: Subsection (d) of section 151 is amended to remove paragraph (3) and make technical amendments to section 1(f). An inflation adjustment is applied to the dollar amount for taxable years after 1989. The text discusses the repeal of the overall limitation on itemized deductions in Section 68 and includes technical amendments to various sections. The overall limitation on itemized deductions in Section 68 is repealed, with technical amendments to various sections. Clauses (ii), (iii), and (iv) are amended to clauses (i), (ii), and (iii) respectively. The table of sections for part I of subchapter B of chapter 1 is amended by striking the item relating to section 68. These amendments apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001.
